## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020

2 hours

No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 730, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 75, 620, 92]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 134, 583, 153]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 166, 260, 184]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 195, 406, 214]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 214, 603, 250]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 272, 249, 289]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 291, 772, 330]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 346, 520, 383]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[99, 411, 400, 429]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 433, 555, 465]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[99, 488, 357, 506]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 510, 450, 580]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 611, 616, 630]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[99, 644, 178, 662]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 672, 603, 725]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \mathrm{e}^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[99, 766, 262, 784]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 791, 615, 880]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C\] \[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 81, 888, 293]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = |\mathrm{p}(x)|\), where \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is a cubic function. Find the two possible expressions for \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 320, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 435, 94, 454]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 433, 143, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 499, 457]]<|/det|>
Write down the amplitude of \(1 + 4\cos \left(\frac{x}{3}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 435, 920, 455]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 518, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 603, 144, 621]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 597, 806, 625]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 92, 144, 111]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 81, 201, 108]]<|/det|>
Write

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 77, 702, 108]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{\sqrt{p}\big(qr^2\big)^{\frac{1}{3}}}{\big(q^3p\big)^{-1}r^3}\) in the form \(p^a q^b r^c\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 336, 102]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = \frac{\tan 3x}{\sin x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 123, 144, 143]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 120, 473, 149]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) when \(x = \frac{\pi}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 530, 144, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 526, 856, 552]]<|/det|>
Hence find the approximate change in \(y\) as \(x\) increases from \(\frac{\pi}{3}\) to \(\frac{\pi}{3} +h\), where \(h\) is small.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 528, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 668, 143, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 664, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
Given that \(x\) is increasing at the rate of 3 units per second, find the corresponding rate of change in \(y\) when \(x = \frac{\pi}{3}\), giving your answer in its simplest surd form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 682, 920, 702]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 903, 104]]<|/det|>
Find how many different 4-digit numbers can be formed using the digits 1, 3, 4, 6, 7 and 9. Each digit may be used once only in any 4-digit number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 918, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 237, 181, 255]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 237, 730, 255]]<|/det|>
How many of these 4-digit numbers are even and greater than 6000?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 237, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A committee of 5 people is to be formed from 6 doctors, 4 dentists and 3 nurses. Find the number of different committees that could be formed if

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 180, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 384, 135]]<|/det|>
there are no restrictions,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 208, 180, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 207, 527, 225]]<|/det|>
the committee contains at least one doctor,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 208, 920, 225]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 386, 180, 404]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 386, 490, 404]]<|/det|>
the committee contains all the nurses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 386, 920, 404]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 84, 94, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 922, 135]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is initially at the point with position vector \(\begin{pmatrix} 30 \\ 10 \end{pmatrix}\) and moves with a constant speed of \(10 \mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) in the same direction as \(\begin{pmatrix} - 4 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 140, 144, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 139, 447, 159]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector of \(P\) after \(t\) s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 139, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 323, 851, 344]]<|/det|>
As \(P\) starts moving, a particle \(Q\) starts to move such that its position vector after \(t\) s is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 343, 240, 380]]<|/det|>
\[\binom{-80}{90} +t\binom{5}{12}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 401, 144, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 401, 373, 420]]<|/det|>
Write down the speed of \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 401, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 518, 149, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 516, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
Find the exact distance between \(P\) and \(Q\) when \(t = 10\), giving your answer in its simplest surf form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 534, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 504, 101]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 5\ln (2x + 3)\) for \(x > - \frac{3}{2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 109, 144, 128]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 109, 364, 128]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 193, 146, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 193, 393, 212]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 194, 920, 212]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 419, 143, 437]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 416, 920, 452]]<|/det|>

<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 146, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 77, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Solve \(\sin \left(3\phi + \frac{2\pi}{3}\right) = \cos \left(3\phi + \frac{2\pi}{3}\right)\) for \(0 \leqslant \phi \leqslant \frac{2\pi}{3}\) radians, giving your answers in terms of \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 82, 99, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 146, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 76, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\int_{1}^{a}\left(\frac{1}{x} -\frac{1}{2x + 3}\right)\mathrm{d}x = \ln 3,\) where \(a > 0\), find the exact value of \(a\), giving your answer in simplest surd form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
An arithmetic progression has a second term of 8 and a fourth term of 18. Find the least number of terms for which the sum of this progression is greater than 1560.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression has a sum to infinity of 72. The sum of the first 3 terms of this progression is \(\frac{333}{8}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 127, 180, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 127, 475, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the value of the common ratio.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 532, 180, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 532, 490, 551]]<|/det|>
Hence find the value of the first term.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 532, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
